title: Law of Conservation of Energy
definition: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed from one form to another. The total energy in an isolated system remains constant over time.

proofs.description: Verified through countless experiments including Joule's paddle wheel experiment (1845)
proofs.reference: Joule, J. P. (1847). On the Mechanical Equivalent of Heat

proofs.description: Noether's theorem (1918) links energy conservation to time translation symmetry

difficulty_levels.beginner: Energy doesn't disappear, it just changes form (like water changing to ice or steam)
difficulty_levels.intermediate: The total energy in an isolated system remains constant regardless of internal changes
difficulty_levels.expert: Energy conservation emerges from time translation symmetry via Noether's theorem in Lagrangian mechanics

extra_fields.key_discoverers: Julius Robert von Mayer, James Prescott Joule, Hermann von Helmholtz
extra_fields.significance: Fundamental constraint on all physical processes
everyday_examples: Roller coaster: potential → kinetic → thermal energy
